heading: How do the tax revenues on labour and capital differ across the EU27?
subheading: In 2022 the tax revenues between labour and capital in the EU27 averaged 2.29. Showing that labour-based tax revenues are 2.29 times higher than capital-based tax revenues.
textNote: The Labour-to-Capital Ratio reveals that, on average, EU countries tax labour significantly more than capital, with higher ratios indicating a greater reliance on income from wages and social contributions for public revenue, while lower ratios suggest a more balanced or capital-focused tax policy aimed at attracting investments.
